title: Panel on police suicides says officers need better mental health support | CBC News
text:
A panel put together by Ontario's Chief Coroner says the province's police officers need better, more clear mental health and suicide prevention resources.

The report, released Wednesday, was written by a panel of people in the policing community and mental health professionals.

It was formed after nine officers killed themselves in 2018 and happened to be released just days after an Ottawa police officer also died by suicide at police headquarters on Friday.

The report stresses the need to end the stigma around mental health issues, not only for police members, but the public as well.

That normalization should extend from basic training through an officer's career, it says.

Among the panel's 14 recommendations is the creation of an Ontario Police Members Mental Health Collaborative (OPMMHC) made up of members from police service boards, police associations, police officers, their family members, and mental health providers.

It suggests the group find gaps and overlaps in the mental health support network, reporting on their progress twice a year to the office of the solicitor general, who's responsible for law enforcement in Ontario.

It would help reduce barriers for members needing immediate help by encouraging a "no-wrong-door" mindset across the province where there aren't any barriers to getting mental health support.

It also states the chief coroner's office will create policy to keep track of any first responder suicides and hold a "death review committee" for each one, saying there's currently no requirement to track these deaths.
